results.webTitle: Football transfer rumours: Lacazette or Aubameyang to Barcelona?

fields.body:
Barcelona want to sell Martin Braithwaite and sign another striker, and the Spanish newspaper Sport reports that both Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang and Alexandre Lacazette are on their shortlist, and that Arsenal would be willing to sell either of them. â€œBarÃ§a would only be able to sign one,â€ warns Sport, â€œand wouldnâ€™t be able to pay a fee for either player.â€ The Arsenal suits might stop reading there, and therefore miss the bit about any deal having to be in the form of a player exchange.

Related: Nuno expects Kane to â€˜get readyâ€™ after Spurs upset Manchester City

The Gunners are after a new striker of their own in the shape of Internazionaleâ€™s Lautaro MartÃ­nez and, if Tuttosport is to be believed, might end up attempting a swoop for both the Argentinian and the clubâ€™s former manager, Antonio Conte, unless Mikel Arteta manages to coax a significant improvement out of his team over the next week or two.

Tottenham have also been looking to Italy for potential signings, with the London club having contacted Cagliari to ask if they might kindly consider letting them have the Uruguayan midfielder Nahitan NÃ¡ndez. Then thereâ€™s the Japanese defender Takehiro Tomiyasu, who has been linked with both Spurs and Leicester, with news that his current employers, Bologna, are showing interest in the Argentinian defender Andres Herrera suggesting they might be preparing to lose the 22-year-old. He wouldnâ€™t be the first defender Spurs have tried to sign this summer â€“ Marca reports that Villarrealâ€™s Pau Torres turned them down because he wants to play in the Champions League.

Thatâ€™s not all that Marca is reporting: on its front page it trumpets news that Real Madridâ€™s pursuit of Kylian MbappÃ© has â€œentered its decisive phase this weekâ€, though inside the tune changes slightly, with the assertion that â€œwe are entering the decisive two weeksâ€. Either way, this is part of the decisive timeframe. The Spaniards are ready to make an offer but, with the player in the final year of his contract and pressure building in Paris for him to extend, they are â€œwaiting for the tension between MbappÃ© and PSG to reach a peak before they make their moveâ€.

â€œWe need to find quality,â€ said Sean Dyche after Burnley lost at home against Brighton on the seasonâ€™s opening weekend, though he added that â€œnothing is imminentâ€ despite rumours linking them to Maxwel Cornet, among others. They are said to have outbid Hertha Berlin for Cornet with an offer of around Â£12m, though the player did not exactly encourage their interest as he was sent off in Lyonâ€™s first match of the Ligue 1 season, which they lost 3-0 against Angers on Sunday â€“ the player obviously taking the name of their opponents a little too literally. The Mail points out that Burnleyâ€™s last senior signing from a foreign club was Steve Defour from Anderlecht in 2016.

The Times also reports that three Premier League clubs are squabbling over Divock Origi, with Wolves, West Ham and Crystal Palace all interested in the Belgian, who joined Liverpool when he was 19, is now 26, has started 63 games for the club in all competitions at the rate of nine a year (though he has been out on loan for some of them), and has very little to show for all those years except quite a lot of medals. Wolves have also been linked with the 24-year-old Guinean midfielder Amadou Diawara, and are said to have had a chat about him with Roma suits while they were in England to discuss Tammy Abrahamâ€™s move from Chelsea.

Southamptonâ€™s pursuit of a new defender following the departure of Jannik Vestergaard has taken them to the door of Gary Cahill, who at 35 is a free agent after leaving Crystal Palace, though the times reports cryptically that â€œthey are in talks with defenders based abroadâ€. And Manchester City have taken an unexpected interest in the Solihull Moors striker Kyle Hudlin, who could not be less of an obvious fit for Pep Guardiolaâ€™s team of nimble, diminutive forwards â€“ the 21-year-old is 6ft 9in, and also on the radar of Middlesbrough and Cardiff.

results.webTitle: Football transfer rumours: Kylian MbappÃ© to Real Madrid?

fields.body:
Few things tickle the nationâ€™s funny bones like those hi-la-rious social-media quips from unlikely small clubs about their supposed interest in megastars. â€œWeâ€™d like to play down any rumours linking Dynamo Catford with Lionel Messiâ€ â€“ that kind of thing. And whaddya know, it looks like some wags at Manchester United have got in on the act, with the Daily Star reporting that â€œwhile the move to Paris still seems likelyâ€, United are rumoured to be considering a late bid to lure the Argentina forward away from Paris Saint-Germain and to Old Trafford.

Related: â€˜Itâ€™s not about making moneyâ€™: the former footballers working as agents

The Qatar-backed project are of course licking their lips at the idea of Messi linking up with Neymar and Kylian MbappÃ© but, whatâ€™s this? Real Madrid fancy swooping for MbappÃ© and could even do so this summer, according to their midfielder Toni Kroos. The France forward is entering the final year of his contract and Kroos reportedly â€œwouldnâ€™t be surprisedâ€ if he pitched up at the BernabÃ©u this summer, despite Real â€“ like Barcelona â€“ being totally hobbled by financial restraints that are absolutely nothing to do with them and everything to do with the rest of football for merely existing.

A more plausible Manchester United-related slice of tittle-tattle might be the departure of Anthony Martial to Internazionale for Â£50m as the Italian champions seek to fill the impending Romelu Lukaku-shaped hole in their attack. Inter reportedly want to try out the French forward on a one-year loan deal before any permanent deal but the Sun says United are keen on a full and immediate sale.

Another possible outgoing could be Jesse Lingard. Fresh from helping West Ham into Europe when on loan there last season, the winger might tickle Leicesterâ€™s fancy should James Maddison leave. Brendan Rodgers is also thought to be eyeing up Ozan Kabak. The Schalke defender and Turkey international gained some mixed Premier League experience last season as a Liverpool loanee, but is apparently up for some more at the King Power Stadium. West Hamâ€™s Issa Diop is also on Leicesterâ€™s radar.

Meanwhile, Liverpoolâ€™s Xherdan Shaqiri, having done his usual thing of stepping out of the shadows to remind the world of his existence at an international tournament, is of interest to Lyon. Lâ€™Equipe reports the French club have made a bid for the Switzerland playmaker that, although only thought to be around â‚¬5m-â‚¬7m, would also cost Lyon a fair old wedge in wages. And talking of people who looked good on the telly over the summer, coming in at Anfield could be the teenage Rennes and Belgium winger JÃ©rÃ©my Doku.

JosÃ© Mourinho could be poised to add another loan spell to Tammy Abrahamâ€™s CV and this one could turn permanent, with the Mail reporting that Roma have made a Â£34m offer. Chelsea are keen on an outright sale and Roma face competition for the 23-year-old forward from Arsenal and Atalanta.

And finally Brentford are interested in the Blackburn midfielder Joe Rothwell, who could be available on the cheap as his contract at Ewood Park heads into its final year. A bit of down-to-earth realism to round things off.

results.webTitle: Football transfer rumours: Oxlade-Chamberlain back to Southampton?

fields.body:
Start all the clocks, plug in the telephone â€¦ Joe Willockâ€™s to sign following his half-season loan. Yes, the Millâ€™s back, albeit operating on pandemic-enforced â€œhalf-powerâ€ mode.

â€œWhere have you been? What have we missed? Feed me etc,â€ we hear you cry (one email and counting). To bring you up to speed, the window so far has been a typically elaborate session of Cones of Dunshire, with long pre-announced England striker departure getting messy and Lionel Messi testing the salt-water-repelling properties of a lectern as he laments leaving Barcelona, (checks notes) contrary to his wishes.

Related: Six young players to look out for in the Premier League this season

With either Manchester City or Nuno looking to get their way re: Harry Kane, and PSG simply the only option for Messi if weâ€™re all abiding by both the spirit and the letter of financial fair play, probably best to find other levels to this summerâ€™s 3D chess.

With that in mind: howsabout Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain back to Southampton. The suddenly 27-year-old, having slotted seamlessly into the Adam Lallana role of â€œback from injury problems but not really trusted to actually play all that muchâ€ at Liverpool, is being lined up for what one source comically refers to as an â€œambitiousâ€ move by the Saints, who he left a full decade ago this very week.

Potentially on the way out of St Maryâ€™s is Jannik Vestergaard, with Brendan Rodgers once again finding himself light on defenders at Leicester after Wesley Fofanaâ€™s grim fibula fracture. West Ham are also having a look-see at the stern Danish defender.

Back in L4, JÃ¼rgen Klopp is apparently eyeing AurÃ©lien Tchouameni to fill the hole in the middle of Anfield ploughed by Georginio Wijnaldum. The France Under-21s midfielder, who enjoyed a breakthrough season at Monaco last time out, is also the subject of fluttering eyelashes from Juventus.

Tammy Abraham has read Tommy Tuchelâ€™s tealeaves at Chelsea, and with Romelu Lukaku seemingly on the way, the occasional England forward will be making his own way to the Do One Door ta very much. JosÃ© Mourinho may be the man sending a car, with Roma really quite interested, and â€œlong-term replacement for Edin Dzekoâ€ the label on the poisoned chalice that potentially awaits.

Last but by no means least, Willockâ€™s expected permanent move to St Jamesâ€™ Park could help untangle the kite string keeping Mikel Arteta from Aaron Ramsdale. Sheffield United, who were looking around bemused, wondering quite what they would do without him, have now realised that another keeper is probably the answer, with QPRâ€™s Seny Dieng looking just the man.

results.webTitle: Football should consider eliminating heading, dementia expert says

fields.body:
Football should consider eliminating heading, the leading researcher into dementia in the sport has said, after new evidence provided â€œthe missing linkâ€ between repeated heading and neurodegenerative disease.

Dr Willie Stewart of the University of Glasgow, who leads the landmark Field study, says the game must ask whether heading is â€œabsolutely necessaryâ€. Football, he said, should now come with a health warning attached.

Related: Concerns raised over how football clubs will enforce new heading restrictions

Previous results from the Field study â€“ its name derived from â€œfootballâ€™s influence on lifelong health and dementia riskâ€ â€“ had shown that former professionals were 3.5 times more likely to die with dementia than the general public. The findings brought to the fore the issue of brain injury in the sport but authorities frequently insisted more research was necessary before a link with heading could be confirmed. Stewart says that connection can now be shown and called for authorities to act.

â€œWith the current data weâ€™re now at the point to suggest that football should be sold with a health warning saying repeated heading in football may lead to an increased risk of dementia,â€ he said. â€œThatâ€™s where we are now, that cannot be ignored.

â€œIn the previous study we didnâ€™t have sufficient data to be able to look at the important factor: exposure to football. What we could say last time was that being a footballer meant your risk of dying with a degenerative brain disease was higher, but we couldnâ€™t say what in football was doing it.

Related: Football without headers is unthinkable â€“ or is it? | Adrian Chiles

â€œNow, through using our surrogates for exposure to heading and brain injury, which are field position and length of playing the game, we can see that if youâ€™re in a position where youâ€™re exposed to a high level of head impacts or you play the game longer, your risk is higher.â€

The new research, published in the journal JAMA Neurology, finds that risk of neurodegenerative disease in former professional footballers varies by player position and career length, but not by playing era. Whereas goalkeepers, who rarely head the ball, have a risk statistically indistinguishable from that of a control group, defenders â€“ who head the ball the most â€“ have a five-fold risk of developing neurodegenerative disease. That risk increases the longer a playerâ€™s career goes on and the risk did not change across the 7,676 players the study analysed, despite their dates of birth ranging from 1900 to 1976.

â€œThe data from this paper is the missing link in trying to understand this connection between sport and dementia,â€ Stewart said. â€œWe put that together with what we know about the mortality risk â€¦ and there really isnâ€™t anything else. There is no other proposed risk factor and this is one we could really address and eliminate this disease.

â€œI think football has to ask the difficult questions: is heading absolutely necessary to the game of football? Is potential exposure to degenerative brain disease absolutely necessary? Or can some other form of the game be considered?â€

The Field study is funded by the Football Association and the Professional Footballersâ€™ Association but Stewart was critical of the measures the professional game has undertaken to limit the risk from heading. Last week the FA, Premier League and EFL, endorsed by the playersâ€™ union, announced guidelines limiting â€œhigh-impactâ€ headers to 10 a week in training. The rules were implemented as a precautionary measure, but Stewart criticised them, saying they were â€œnot based in scienceâ€ and arguing no category of header created less risk.

â€œIf we think that heading in professional football is necessary and the risk of dementia is necessary then perhaps what football should be doing rather than considering concussion substitute protocols that donâ€™t really stand up or limitations on heading in training which have no basis in science, they should be thinking about what football would look like without heading,â€ he said. â€œLetâ€™s try that.â€

results.webTitle: Football transfer rumours: Robert Lewandowski to exit Bayern Munich?

fields.body:
This is not a drill: Robert Lewandowski wants to leave Bayern Munich. Sky Sports has reported that the Poland international is disappointed not to have been offered a contract extension by the German giants and is now open to leaving the club this month.

Lewandowski has two years left on his deal and, given he scored 361 goals last season, itâ€™s not hard to imagine plenty of big clubs being interested in him â€“ even if Bayernâ€™s Â£100m-plus valuation may yet prove a stumbling block for even the richest of them.

Related: Can Italyâ€™s golden sporting summer help to revive the ailing Serie A?

The Pole, who scored in Bayernâ€™s opening Bundesliga draw against MÃ¶nchengladbach last Friday, and twice in the Super Cup victory against Borussia Dortmund on Tuesday, is presumably calculating that heâ€™s got one big-money move remaining in his career. North of Â£100m for a player of his age may sound a bit toppy, but the Mill reckons Lewandowski, who turns 33 on Saturday, still has several more years at the top.

With regards to another Â£100m-plus forward, Harry Kane, the Tottenham manager Nuno EspÃ­rito Santo is visibly losing the will to live with the incessant questions. â€œWhat matters is what is happening behind the doors, and what is happening behind the doors is Harry is our player,â€ he has patiently explained. The Mail reports that if Kane does leave Spurs, the north London club will bid for Adama TraorÃ© from Wolves, while the Times reckons Tottenham are stepping up their chase for the Serbia defender Nikola Milenkovic from Fiorentina, who would set them back about Â£13m.

Also in Italy, the former Chelsea forward Pedro is poised to be reunited with his old Stamford Bridge gaffer Maurizio Sarri at Lazio after spending one fruitful season at Roma. Fabrizio Romano reports that the former BarÃ§a man will move across the Italian capital on a free transfer. JosÃ© Mourinho has just taken the reins at Roma, and the Mirror reckons he was determined to get shot of Pedro after he made disparaging comments in an interview with the Telegraph that everyone else had forgotten.

The news from almost-permanent-crisis-club Arsenal is positive: the on-off deal for the Sheffield United goalkeeper Aaron Ramsdale is happening after all, for an initial fee of Â£24m. The deal to sign Martin Ã˜degaard full-time is also well on the way to becoming reality. Another Madridista, Marco Asensio, is also being touted as a potential target for Mikel Arteta and his sidekick Edu.

Manchester United remain keen to sign another midfielder before the transfer window slams shut at the end of the month and a name that has reportedly appeared on their radar is the Monaco youngster AurÃ©lien TchouamÃ©ni. The 21-year-old defensive midfielder established himself in Ligue 1 last season and also impressed at the Under-21 European Championship.

Related: Menâ€™s transfer window summer 2021 â€“ all deals from Europeâ€™s top five leagues

The 18-year-old Eduardo Camavinga, of Rennes, is another name that keeps cropping up and slightly bizarrely, some are saying this Instagram photo of his Rennes kit hanging in the changing room amounts to a cryptic goodbye. Brightonâ€™s Yves Bissouma has also been linked with a move to Old Trafford. â€œI canâ€™t control the future, I donâ€™t know whatâ€™s going to happen, essentially,â€ the Brighton manager, Graham Potter, philosophised last week. â€œThatâ€™s the beauty of life and football.â€

In other news, the Premier League new boys Watford are going to buy the Turkey international Ozan Tufan from Fenerbahce, the Athletic reports, while the Hornets have rejected a Â£5m offer from Crystal Palace for Will Hughes, says the Sun.

Newcastleâ€™s midfield looks sets for a shake-up with Everton and Southampton both keen to buy Sean Longstaff. The Magpies are said to want Â£10m for the 23-year-old. The former Chelsea stalwart Gary Cahill will have a medical at Bournemouth and will sign a one-year deal on the south coast.

results.webTitle: Which football managers have crossed acrimonious derby divides? | The Knowledge

fields.body:
â€œFormer Liverpool manager Rafa BenÃ­tezâ€™s appointment at Everton was surprising. Is there a more jaw-dropping example of a manager crossing an acrimonious derby divide (perhaps even directly)?â€ asks George Jones.

Andy Grace is a Southampton fan who never forgets. â€œBenÃ­tez, once of Liverpool now Everton? Not even close. Derbies donâ€™t come any more acrimonious than the one on the south coast. Harry Redknapp going directly from Portsmouth to Southampton and back to (his spiritual home) Portsmouth surely takes some beating.â€

Chris Richardson puts the spotlight on the West Midlands. â€œRon Saunders took Aston Villa to their first (and most recent) top-flight title in 71 years during the 1980-81 season. Having steered Villa to the quarter-finals of the European Cup the following year, he resigned over a contract dispute and relocated 3.5 miles to arch-rivals Birmingham City (also then in Division One). Birminghamâ€™s first home fixture after Saundersâ€™ arrival was a 1-0 loss to Villa during which much of the opposition fansâ€™ singing (to the tune of Bread of Heaven) was â€˜Ron Saunders, Ron Saunders, you must be [eff]ing madâ€™. Perhaps this was warranted because Saundersâ€™ assistant Tony Barton won the European Cup with the Villa team Saunders created, while Birmingham were promptly relegated. Birmingham gained promotion the next season but he ditched them for ever-so-slightly-less arch-rivals West Brom, who were also immediately relegated.â€

The north London Derby can provide us with a couple of examples of derby divide-crossing managers. â€œA good one is Arsenal stalwart Terry Neill,â€ writes Mitchell Sandler. â€œHaving left Highbury in 1970 to become player-manager at Hull, he impressed enough to become the successor to Bill Nicholson at Spurs in 1974. Perhaps inevitably, following Bertie Meeâ€™s retirement two years later, he was top of a very short list when the Arsenal board looked for a replacement and he jumped at the chance to take the Gunners job.â€ Meanwhile, Ed Mortimer offers up George Graham. â€œA former player and manager of Arsenal, he took over at Tottenham [via Leeds]. Apparently Spurs even won some silverware, though itâ€™s a technicality as trophies won with a Gooner in charge clearly canâ€™t be counted.â€ Oh behave, Ed.

Radomir AntiÄ‡ managed Real Madrid, AtlÃ©tico Madrid and Barcelona but never moved directly between those clubs and Ernest Mangnall, the owner of a glorious moustache, crossed the Manchester derby divide in 1912. He began a 12-year stint at City having spent nine years at United, where he won two league titles and an FA Cup. He won nothing at City.

Qualifying to play for numerous national teams

â€œWhich player (active or retired) has been eligible to play for the highest number of different national teams?â€ asks Ben Janeson. â€œAnd other than Alfredo Di StÃ©fano, have any players played for three different national teams (not counting cases such as USSR/Russia or Yugoslavia/Serbia etc)?â€

Letâ€™s start with the first part. â€œAdnan Januzaj was qualified to play for six different national teams (Belgium, Albania, Kosovo, Serbia, Turkey and Croatia), but not England, despite what was said at the time,â€ offers Jerry Higgins, setting the bar so high that it might take an extraordinary person to beat it.

â€œBorn on a refugee raft, Rio Mavuba was eligible for all of them,â€ writes Steve Hyde, with perfect timing. Mavuba was born in international waters off the coast of west Africa while fleeing the Angola civil war en route to France, where he settled and earned 13 caps for Les Bleus after turning down the chance to play for DR Congo. And while it might be true that Mavuba could have, theoretically, represented any nation, Fifaâ€™s eligibility rules say a stateless person must have lived in the country they hope to represent for at least five years and demonstrate that the move to the territory of the association was not for the purpose of participating for its representative teams. So, in practical terms, a stateless person is not eligible for any nation until they have settled somewhere for a length of time.â€

As for the second element, Milton offers up a near-miss in Daniel Alberto Brailovsky, who played for Uruguay Under-20s, unofficial matches for Argentina and then 18 times for Israel, scoring three goals. But David Walker has another big-name striker to match Di StÃ©fano: â€œLÃ¡szlÃ³ Kubala, the famous Barcelona centre-forward, played for Czechoslovakia, his native Hungary and Spain. Like StÃ©fano, despite playing for three different countries he never appeared in the final stages of either a World Cup or European Championship. Both players were included in Spainâ€™s squad for the 1962 World Cup finals in Chile, but, owing to injury, neither appeared in a match.â€

Winning big with a nation you never played club football in

â€œDespite winning Euro 2020 with Italy Marco Verratti has never played a Serie A game. Has anyone else won major international tournament with their national team despite never having played a top flight game in that country?â€ asks Dan Almond.

â€œThat happened the day before with a player of lesser stature than Verratti,â€ writes Thomas Wendt, clearly building up to something. â€œA little known player called Lionel Messi won the Copa AmÃ©rica, despite never playing a club match in Argentina. In the same squad, there was also Aston Villaâ€™s Emiliano MartÃ­nez, who has never played a top-flight match in Argentina, having been signed by Arsenal as a youth player.

â€œPaul Pogba has never played a game in France yet won the World Cup with them. He was signed by Manchester United from Le Havre as a youth-team player. And Antoine Griezmann shared the same glory despite having never played a senior game in France. He was signed by Real Sociedad (from Macon in the French sixth division) as a 14-year-old.â€

Knowledge archive

â€œIâ€™ve been wondering for a while what I should call any prospective son to give him the best chance of success at professional football,â€ wrote Nick Pepper, in August 2010. â€œSo my question is what is the most successful first name and surname in football in terms of trophies and titles won?â€

â€œAlthough Iâ€™m inclined to say that, of Englishmen at least, Robert â€“ shortened to Bob (by) â€“ must top the bill (having provided World Cup success with Charlton and Moore, and exceptional managerial achievements for Paisley and Robson), Iâ€™ve no evidence of that,â€ wrote Robert D Marriott. â€œThe most successful English player in terms of trophies won was Phil Neal, who collected four European Cups, one Uefa Cup, eight league titles, four League Cups, one European Super Cup, five Charity Shields, and one, er, Sherpa Van Trophy [while managing Bolton]. And no end of runners-up medals. Whatâ€™s more, his surname can be used too, so Iâ€™d expect a Phillip George Neal Pepper to be playing for England in about 20 yearsâ€™ time.â€

Can you help?

â€œWe all know of footballers who played cricket, but did any ever compete at the Olympics?â€ asks Harvey Mayne, presumably meaning in other sports.

â€œWith Rogelio Funes Mori making his debut for Mexico this week, does this make him and his brother Ramiro the first identical twins to play for different national teams?â€ wonders Logan Casey.

Email your questions and answers to knowledge@theguardian.com or tweet @TheKnowledge_GU.

results.webTitle: Sweet FA review â€“ womenâ€™s football saga staged at Tynecastle

fields.body:
It was a day of celebration. The players from the North British Rubber Company (NBRC) in Edinburghâ€™s Fountainbridge had been pitched against their rivals from Ramage & Ferguson shipbuilders at no less a ground than Tynecastle Park, home of Heart of Midlothian football club.

But it was also a day of tragedy. This was July 1916 and in the far-away Somme, the very men whom NBRC had been supplying with wellington boots were suffering catastrophic losses.

This is the compelling tension underscoring Sweet FA, the story of the workplace womenâ€™s football teams who enjoyed enormous popularity during the first world war.

Itâ€™s a bittersweet tale. On the one hand, the conflict gave the women unparalleled opportunities at work and play; on the other, it robbed them of brothers, sons and husbands. That the womenâ€™s game would be curtailed by a postwar ban lasting 50 years only adds to the injustice.

And where better to tell this tale than on a stage perched on Tynecastleâ€™s main stand, with the empty stadium as its backdrop? Performed by a tremendous nine-strong ensemble, the play by Paul Beeson and Tim Barrow draws on the popular theatre tradition laid down by 7:84 and Wildcat to blend community history and original songs by Matthew Brown in a lively, polemical show.

There is a lot of history to distil â€“ what with suffragettes, the 1918 flu pandemic and the machinations of the football authorities â€“ and the play could do with a little less of it, but Bruce Strachanâ€™s production is sharp, funny and well-drilled.

From Rachel Millarâ€™s Alice, with her sights on Prestonâ€™s unbeatable Dick, Kerr Ladies, to Heather Cochraneâ€™s Helen, with her hidden coaching skills, the cast have the coordination and sparkle of Premier League champions.

  • Sweet FA is at Tynecastle Park, Edinburgh, until 30 August.

results.webTitle: Football transfer rumours: Ander Herrera back to Manchester United?

fields.body:
Leo Messiâ€™s dreams of lining up in the same Paris Saint-Germain team as Ander Herrera, Mauro Icardi and Idrissa Gueye could be dashed, following reports from Spain that the trio are among up to 10 players the French side are hoping to offload in a bid to trim their ludicrously large wage bill after their low-key signing of the Argentinian free agent.

Quite who they hope will buy them is anyoneâ€™s guess, given the manner in which theyâ€™ve completely distorted the European market by offering absurdly bloated salaries â€“ even by the standards of football â€“ that few if any European clubs will be able to match.

Related: Menâ€™s transfer window summer 2021 â€“ all deals from Europeâ€™s top five leagues

For what itâ€™s worth, the striker Icardi has recently been linked with a move to Roma as a potential replacement for Internazionale-bound Edin Dzeko, while a possible return to Manchester United for the popular Herrera doesnâ€™t seem beyond the realms of possibility. Sensible chap that he is, Gueye has already turned up his nose at the prospect of a loan move to Newcastle.

Tammy Abraham is another striker being linked with Roma, a state of affairs that hasnâ€™t precluded Thomas Tuchel from including the 23-year-old in Chelseaâ€™s squad for Wednesday nightâ€™s Uefa Super Cup ding-dong with Villarreal. The player himself is reported to be eager to stay in the Premier League and has already agreed personal terms with Arsenal. Speaking before the match at Belfastâ€™s Windsor Park, Tuchel refused to give any clues on what the short-term future holds for Abraham but did confirm he understood the playerâ€™s dissatisfaction with life at Stamford Bridge.

â€œHe has reason not to be happy after the lack of game time last season but itâ€™s maybe also my fault for not trusting him as much as other players,â€ said the German. â€œHe wants more minutes so the decision will be does he want to fight his way back into the team here or does he want to change to be a regular starter elsewhere?

â€œThatâ€™s completely up to him and I understand, itâ€™s quite a normal situation. But right now heâ€™s with us and available for the team tomorrow.â€

With Jonny Evans and Wesley Fofana sidelined indefinitely, Leicester are in the market for a central defender and have identified Southamptonâ€™s Jannik Vestergaard as just the man to fill the gaping hole in their back four. Valued at between Â£15m and Â£20m with only two years left on his current deal, the 29-year-old Dane has also been getting the glad eye from West Ham boss David Moyes and is believed to be keen on a move away from the south coast.

Leicester are also believed to be interested in Bolognaâ€™s Takehiro Tomiyasu but will have to outbid Tottenham if they are to secure the Japanese 22-year-oldâ€™s scrawl.

And finally, the Royal Antwerp right-back AurÃ©lio Buta is wanted by Celtic, whose hopes of luring him to Glasgow have been dealt what can only be described as â€œa blowâ€ by reported interest from Everton. The Angola-born former Portugal youth international is reported to be available for less than Â£5m and is apparently viewed by Everton scouts as an upgrade on Jonjoe Kenny, who is currently first in line to Seamus Colemanâ€™s right-back throne.

results.webTitle: Womenâ€™s Olympics football: quarter-finals tie-by-tie analysis | Suzanne Wrack

fields.body:
Team GB v Australia (in Kashima)

Australia qualified for the knockout stage as one of two best third-place teams but their tournament has not been a bad one. Predictably, the Chelsea forward and WSL golden boot winner Sam Kerr has led the way, scoring three of the Matildasâ€™ four goals. She scored an equaliser for Australia against in-form Sweden and then gave her side the lead before they succumbed to a 4-2 defeat. Against the World-Cup winning US womenâ€™s national team Australia dominated possession and looked the more likely to make the breakthrough for significant portions of their final game in Group G before both sides settled for the draw that sent them both through.

Related: â€˜Itâ€™s crazyâ€™: Ellie Roebuck enjoying Team GB No 1 spot after show of patience

In Team GB they face the team with the best defensive record in the competition, with only one goal conceded. Kerr is a familiar face to most players in the Team GB squad but who that familiarity favours remains to be seen. In the Manchester City forward Ellen White, Team GB boast a star striker who also has three goals to her name. The manager, Hege Riise, made a number of changes to her starting lineup for the final game in Group E with qualification already secured and will have the benefit of some fresher legs going into the quarter-final.

Sweden v Japan (Saitama)

Sweden are the only team to have won all three games in the group stage and will be one of the favourites to reach the final as a result. The shock 3-0 defeat of the World Cup-winners, USA, was a strong statement. In Fridolina RolfÃ¶, Stina Blackstenius, Kosovare Asllani and Sofia Jakobsson they boast a potent front line but the defence is just as formidable with Chelsea duo Magda Eriksson and Jonna Andersson and Bayern Munichâ€™s impressive Hanna Glas conceding just twice.

In Japan they face a team that has struggled to score but which has also conceded just two goals. Manager Asako Takakura took a young team to the World Cup in France two years ago to help prepare for the home Games and while there has been moments in matches where the technical, possession-heavy football so characteristic of the team has shone through, they have been fleeting. Takakuraâ€™s decision to leave out the new Arsenal signing Mana Iwabuchi against Team GB after she had scored the leveller against Canada in their opening game was a strange one. Reinstated to the starting line-up to play Chile, the forward provided the assist for Mina Tanakaâ€™s second-half winner.

Netherlands v USA (Yokohama)

There is no argument, this rematch of the 2019 World Cup final is the tastiest tie of the round. Swedenâ€™s stunning 3-0 defeat of the US has cast a shadow over the USA campaign and it raised the spectre of their 2016 quarter-final elimination to Sweden. USA are not infallible. The decision to scale things back against Australia, playing to avoid defeat, rather than the blazing swagger that is so synonymous with the USWNT, has been widely questioned. That said, they escaped into the knockout stage, having finished second in their group.

USA know they can score against the Netherlands, who have conceded eight goals in their three games despite topping Group F. However, even if you discount the 10 goals the Dutch side put past Olympic newcomers Zambia, they have still scored more than any other team in the tournament (11) with the Arsenal striker Vivianne Miedema firing herself into the record books with eight goals, the most scored by a female player in a single Games with matches still to play. The US have a point to prove but the reigning European champions will be hungry for revenge.

Canada v Brazil (Rifu)

Denied top spot in Group F because of the Netherlandsâ€™ vastly superior goal difference, Brazil ended up with the kinder draw. The SeleÃ§Ã£o have had five different goalscorers across their three games with six-time world player of the year Marta contributing to a third of their nine goals and becoming the first player to score at five consecutive Olympics.

Related: Elastic Australia show different face in Olympic football draw with USA | Samantha Lewis

In Canada, Brazil come up against a much better defensive unit than that posed by their group opponents. The Canadians conceded a goal a game in Group E, with 84th and 85th minute goals conceded to Japan and Team GB respectively, denying them victory in both matches. Sharpen that focus at the close and Bev Priestmanâ€™s team have a good chance of progressing past their South American opponents, ranked one place above them in the Fifa world rankings. Priestman made six changes to the team that beat Chile for Canadaâ€™s final group game against Team GB, having already secured passage to the knockout stage. She rested the worldâ€™s international record goalscorer, Christine Sinclair, entirely and made two half-time substitutions all with an eye on their next game and the tight turnaround. Brazil can be buoyed by the fact that they twice came from behind against the Netherlands and took the lead before the game finished 3-3 in their toughest test to date.

results.webTitle: The Euro 2020 Fiver: meanwhile, in club football â€¦

fields.body:
PUTTING THE NOT EURO 2020 INTO EURO NOT 2020

Allegations have been made that if you read The Fiver backwards it contains hidden messages, often Satanic. There have also been claims that if you read it the right way, The Fiver is witty. A load of xollob, naturally. But rumours can stick so we feel obliged to declare loud and clear that The Fiver has never knowingly provoked laughter, nor does it see eye to eye with the devil, whose insistence on making work for idle hands has never slouched right with us. That does invoke one pertinent question, though: what becomes of idle feet?

Related: Rafael BenÃ­tez is a gamble that could expose Evertonâ€™s wider fragility | Andy Hunter

That, of course, is a pressing issue and not just because EN 2020 has been paused to allow Uefa to consider whether to play the tournament to a conclusion or just hand the trophy right now to England and their ruth captain, Sir Harry of Goals. While an entire continent waits for the suits to finish their deliberations, which are already on to a fifth course, club football has been carrying on with such vigour that even Daniel Levy has finally been able to find work for idle hands, deciding that Tottenham Hotspurâ€™s future will be determined by Nuno EspÃ­rito Santoâ€™s ability to revive Matt Doherty. Everton, meanwhile, have announced that Rafa BenÃ­tez is in for a hell of a season.

In south London, meanwhile, Crystal Palace fans eagerly await official confirmation that they have a new manager, with leading candidate Patrick Vieira understood to be seeking clarification as to what the floppy-haired man with the blue and red tie meant when he said that, contractually speaking, Lionel Messi is now as much a part of the furniture at Selhurst Park as Wayne Hennessey, Joel Ward, Scott Dann, Nathaniel Clyne, Mamadou Sakho, Andros Townsend, Gary Cahill, James McCarthy and Connor Wickham.

LIVE ON BIG WEBSITE!

Itâ€™s just the Euros blog, which is here.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

â€œHeâ€™s mad humbleâ€ â€“ David Sesay, former teammate of Jadon Sancho during his formative years, gives an insight to the England player, who is on his way to Manchester United in a Â£73m deal.

FIVER LETTERS

â€œI am English by birth (although with a Croatian father) and have lived in Australia for more than 20 flaminâ€™ years. Football is about as likely to come home as I amâ€ â€“ Julian Busic.

â€œI have a great deal of respect for your fine, erudite and incredibly knowledgeable publication. No, really! However, $exually Repressed Morris Dancing Fiver seems to get a lot of bad press from you. Having said that, when I suggested to my better half that I would like to start a flaminâ€™ Morris dancing â€˜sideâ€™ here in Robertson, New South Wales, her response was: â€˜If thatâ€™s on, then weâ€™re then weâ€™re not!â€™ And quoted Lysistrata to make her point. Iâ€™m guessing $exually repressed Morris Dancing Fiver chose dancingâ€ â€“ Tim Allen.

Send your letters to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can always tweet The Fiver via @guardian_sport. Todayâ€™s winner of our prizeless letter oâ€™ the day is â€¦ Tim Allen.

NEWS, BITS AND BOBS

Germanyâ€™s interior minister has hit out at Uefa for allowing big crowds at the tournament during a spike in the coronavirus crisis from the Delta variant. â€œUefaâ€™s position is utterly irresponsible,â€ fumed Horst Seehofer. â€œI cannot explain why Uefa is not being sensible â€¦ I suspect it is due to commercialism.â€

Speaking of which, data published by Public Health Scotland shows that 1,991 people who later tested positive had attended one or more Euro 2020 events during their infection period, a time when they â€œmay have unknowingly transmitted their infection to othersâ€. Nearly two-thirds of cases reported travelling to London for the game against England.

Expatriate England fans look like theyâ€™ll have to provide the non-band backing in the Rome quarter-final against Ukraine. â€œI do think thereâ€™s quite an army out there that might show up,â€ Itâ€™s Coming Homed Mary Handley, who lives in Italy. â€œIf I can do it, Iâ€™m ready to do it, absolutely. We just need the authorities to help us out. I think the expats will respond to this, especially as the expat community tends to be â€“ how can I put this â€“ in the older bracket. So we probably all have our Italian vaccinations and we can get into the stadium without jumping through any more hoops.â€

Ukraine striker Artem Besedin could be sidelined for up to six months by the knee-knack suffered in Marcus Danielsonâ€™s red-card challenge against Sweden. â€œHe is a fighter and said that even if he had his time over, he would not take away his leg and would still go to the end for the victory of our team,â€ tub-thumped UAF president Andriy Pavelko. â€œThis is the manifestation of his true human and fighting qualities.â€

Spain keeper Unai SimÃ³n insists the team arenâ€™t glad to have avoided France after they lost to Switzerland. â€œItâ€™s a quarter-final tie, we donâ€™t depend on our opponents, we depend on ourselves,â€ he roared. â€œWe play to win this Euros and we donâ€™t mind who we play, to win this tournament we have to face the best teams.â€

And Belgiumâ€™s Dries Mertens is looking forward more than most to Fridayâ€™s quarter-final with Italy. â€œIt is special to play against Italy because Iâ€™ve lived there for the last eight years and I know all their players,â€ tooted the Napoli man.

NON EUROS BUSINESS

Er, think we covered that earlier. Hang on â€¦ Declan Rice has turned down two contract offers from West Ham and wants to be informed of any bids amid interest from English clubs in Big Cup.

STILL WANT MORE?

David Hytner hails Raheem Sterlingâ€™s resilience as he rewards Gareth Southgateâ€™s faith and then some.

Jonathan Liew on Englandâ€™s collective triumph.

Marcus Christenson borrows Jonathan Wilsonâ€™s tactics whiteboard, gives it a good disinfecting and explains where Ukraine v England will be won and lost.

Belgium and England are the big climbers in our latest EN 2020 power rankings.

Referees and VAR: good now apparently, writes Paul MacInnes.

Rafa BenÃ­tez has the smarts to succeed at Everton but itâ€™s still a big gamble, warns Andy Hunter.

Catilin Murray assesses the current state of the USA! USA!! USA!!! womenâ€™s team and reckons their Olympic squad can atone for that 2016 flop.

Oh, and if itâ€™s your thing â€¦ you can follow Big Website on Big Social FaceSpace. And INSTACHAT, TOO!

IT WAS JUST MB@NTER
